ygData.subject: Re: first success
ygData.msgSnippet: ... walls. ... we ... implemented ... How did you come up with the range -10 to 10?  That sounds very large for a normal neural network.  A normal NN usually

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "t_bommel" <t_bommel@y...> wrote:
> hey everyone,
> 
> just wanted to let everyone know that i've got my rabbits up and 
> running. they have four camera's for food and four cameras for 
walls. 
> every generation keeps 20 and kill 80 (maybe thats too much). my 
> roommate and i have been working on it the last couple of days so 
we 
> were pretty excited to see them develop. Also, we havent 
implemented 
> neat. we just have 9 inputs going into 2 outputs. however, we've 
> started running into problems that i was hoping to get some advice 
> for.
> 
> first, we have two outputs, if the first output is between -10 and 
> 10, we make it stay, if it is less than -10 we make it go left and 
> right if it is above 10. we do the the same with the other node 
> except for up down. is there a better way to do this?
> 

How did you come up with the range -10 to 10?  That sounds very 
large for a normal neural network.  A normal NN usually only outputs 
values between 0 and 1.

> second, we always seem to have some immediate improvement but then 
> some major stagnation for about 1000 generations then maybe some 
> minor improvements over the next however many generations we run 
it. 
> in our simulated world, rabbits all start in the middle and get 
100 
> moves to get as much food as they can. fitness is defined as how 
many 
> pieces of food you get.
> 

Do you randomize the placement of food?  It is possible sometimes it 
just happens that food is placed in a more easy configuration, or 
rabbits are place relative to each other in a better way.  Do you 
evaluate lots of NN's at the same time (inside many rabbits) or is 
it one NN controlling many rabbits at once?  It is also possible the 
task is very easy and you solved it too fast.  Or, you may need a 
more sophisticated network representation.  1,000 generations of 
stagnation sounds like a really long time, so if it does improve 
later on it's probably just random luck.

> thirdly, can anyone explain the logic behind how neat is 
implemented? 
> for example, with what percentage should a node or connections be 
> added and why?
> 

Have your read our EC paper, looked at our code, and read the NEAT 
FAQ?  I suggest doing those things before asking questions because a 
lot of your first questions will probably be answered.  My version 
of NEAT also comes with a tutorial document.  I am not saying you 
have to use my version, but just that looking over the code and 
tutorial may help you understand it better.  A fair number of people 
here have now implemented NEAT, so I'm sure we can all help you out 
with specific questions.

> finally, we get about 5 sec / 100 generations (with 100 rabbits) 
but 
> that is with extremely limited vision (written in C) if we extend 
the 
> vision one more space in each direction, it drops to about 15 sec/ 
> 100 generations. is this....ok?
> 

That is generally extremely fast.  It means your domain must be very 
simple (and perhaps well-implemented as well).  It makes sense that 
adding sensors increases evaluation time.

Have you observed your rabbits' behavior?  Does it looks reasonable 
and make sense to you?  If so, it's a good sign your metholdogy is 
working.  (It's more important than just looking at the fitness 
graph)

ken
